moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e5: Vidmar uses a Budapest Gambit, a relatively new line at the time. Rubinstein proceeds to badly mishandle the game.
moves.3. dxe5 Ng4 4. Bf4 Nc6 5. Nf3 Bb4+: Rubinstein's greedy insistence on maintaining the Pawn will be punished. Modern players know that often times the best way to deal with a gambit is to return the Pawn at the appropriate time in return for a positional advantage.
moves.6. Nc3 Qe7 7. Qd5 Bxc3+: Forcing an ugly weakness in Rubinstein's Pawn structure.
moves.9. Rc1 f6: Forcing the removal of the advanced KP.
moves.10. exf6 Nxf6: Returning the Knight to its natural square with tempo.
moves.11. Qd2 d6: Opening a line to develop his last minor piece.
moves.12. Nd4 O-O: Tucking his King away before engaging in complications.
moves.14. cxd4 Ne4: Planting his own Knight in a central outpost.
moves.15. Qc2 Qa5+: Forcing Rubinstein's King towards the open spaces.
moves.16. Ke2 Rxf4: A beautiful sacrifice, breaking apart the Pawn-chain shielding the White King.
moves.17. exf4 Bf5: Now threatening 18... N-N6 ch winning Rubinstein's Q on the discovered attack.
moves.18. Qb2 Re8: Now 19... N-N6 dbl ch would win the White KR.
moves.20. Kg3 Ne4+: Driving the King further away from his friends.
moves.23. Bh5 Rxh5+: Another sacrifice, this one drawing the King onto a square from which a deadly double check can be issued.
moves.24. Kxh5 Bg6+: Rubinstein graciously resigns rather than play out the checkmate.

players: Akiba Rubinstein  vs. Dr. Milan Vidmar
